reviewText: Hi Diddle Diddle (1943)I got this one because of Pola Negri--she was funny & believable in her supporing role in this "screwball comedy." It certainly did not hurt her to be in "costumes by Adrian." Fabulous, threadbare as it may be, is the word here for her! Contrary to what I have read, she was quite understandable, making the comments about her being "unitelligible because of her thick, Polish accent" seem like gibberish! She had a bit more accent than Greta Garbo, but there was no problem in being able to understand what she uttered. She was clearly comfortable in comedic and dramatic roles. This one is fluff, but fluff that was well executed. She also was comfortable with the generational jokes being tossed her direction, and handled that with the grace and aplomb one expects from a professional. It will never rival Gone With The Wind, but it's fun, and a must-see for Pola Negri fans!

Billie Burke has just lost her fortune on the eve of her daughter's marriage.  Son-in-law Dennis O'Keefe is convinced his financeer father, Adolphe Menjou, can get it back.  The problem--Menjou is more of a con man  living off a dole from his opera-star wife.  Script is weak, but has its  moments.  I especially like Billie Burke practicing her double-takes.  This  movie, while a pleasant comedy, is not up to O'Keefe's inspired roles in  the original Brewster's Millions and Up in Mabel's Room.
If you like crazy old movies, you will this one!
Quite enjoyable!
love the oldies
I really enjoyed it.
Great rainy Saturday afternoon or late night picture.  Fun reconnecting with the zany non-violent antics of this genre!
Just okay-  like the old fashions, but story so so.
A crazy old film, you won't wonder why you've never heard of it before. Still, it's a fun watch for an old movie buff.

HI DIDDLE DIDDLE (1943) is a delightful screwball comedy with a most unusual cast: Adolphe Menjou, Martha Scott, Pola Negri, Dennis O'Keefe, Billie Burke and June Havoc. Among the uncrediteds are Bess Flowers, Don Brodie and Lou Costello's pal, Bobby Barber. This was silent era star Negri's next-to-last film, Disney's THE MOON-SPINNERS (1964) being her final movie. Here she's hilarious as a pompous Wagnerian opera diva with a voice that penetrates your head like a nail. Whenever Madame Genya Smetana starts to warble, Adolphe Menjou (as Col. Hector Phyffe, an elegant con man) finds a way to escape the noisy onslaught. The colonel's son, played by Dennis O'Keefe, is marrying Martha Scott, the daughter of scatterbrained society dame Billie Burke, who confesses that she's been swindled out of 50K. Menjou is determined to get back this money that was lost at a crooked gambling joint and he enlists the aid of June Havoc, a tall, exotic-looking club singer/dancer. Watch for Havoc's spotlight moment when she stands next to a 7 foot tall Panoram, a big screen TV-like coin-fed contraption that shows musical film clips on demand. June backs up a singing "Soundie" of herself with some jazzy harmony and footwork. Perhaps the best technical gimmick comes at the end. Negri screeches, Menjou winces and illustrations that are duplicated dozens of times on the wallpaper come to life and all run away simultaneously. A fine end to a fun picture! The cast makes the most of some sharp dialogue by Bob Hope's long-time scriptwriter Edmund L. Hartmann. Director Andrew L. Stone may be best known for the musical he worked on just prior to this film, STORMY WEATHER with Lena Horne, Bill 'Bojangles' Robinson, Cab Calloway, Fats Waller, the Nicholas Brothers and Dooley Wilson.

What a cute movie! The comic timing in this movie is hilarious. I laughed out loud several times. Adolphe Menjou steals the show. Reprising his Cafe Metropole lovable-scoundrel skills, I couldn't help but be charmed by him. Great performances and a winning script make this movie a joy from beginning to end. I highly recommend it
This is supposed to be a great classic film, but pictures are in such poor quality it is very difficult to pay attention to this movie.
Billie Burke sitting at a table with a bunch of co-stars practing double takes was the absolute best.
We enjoyed this lighthearted comedy.  The actors all did a fine job.

Couldn't watch this beyond the first fifteen minutes. The audio and lighting were so poor, it made it laborious to continue.  Love old movies and often find gems among them. Unfortunately, this diamond in the rough , needs more help than it has gotten.
A pleasant, totally screwball comedy, packed with characters and action that are not always explained adequately. But who cares?
This is a fun comedy movie.  I liked the acting and the ending with the wallpaper was great. I had not seen that before.
It was fun
This movie is so much fun. I laughed out loud on mor than one occasion!
cute
was just a silly movie with no real plot!! billy Burke was her normal bright bubbly self
this was a fun movie to share with my daughter. i am trying to enrich her with these old time classics. we both enjoyed this movie
